channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Twitter Suspends Hamas Accounts
item.description: The accounts were used by the militant wing of the Palestinian government to directly communicate with the Israel Defense Forces during at 2012 bombing campaign.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of an exchange between an Israeli military spokesman and the military wing of Hamas on Twitter in October.

item.title: The Lede: Al Jazeera Denies That Journalists Detained in Egypt Confessed to Terror Charges
item.description: Egypt said journalists from Al Jazeera English detained on Dec. 29 had “confessed” to being members of the Muslim Brotherhood, but their network denied the claim.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: News Analysis: A Crucial Caveat in Obama’s Vow on Phone Data
item.description: President Obama left the “end” of the bulk telephone data program to another day in a speech partly intended to convince the public that spy programs are being run appropriately.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: 16 Killed, Mostly Foreigners, in Attack on Kabul Restaurant
item.description: The Taliban claimed responsibility for an attack in which a suicide bomber cleared a path for two gunmen, who ran in and opened fire on patrons dining inside.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Afghan security forces assisted an injured man at the site of an explosion in Kabul on Friday.

item.title: No One Will Be Targeted at Olympics, Putin Says
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said visitors to Sochi for the Olympic Games, including gay men and lesbians, could be “relaxed and calm,” but he defended a ban on “homosexual propaganda.”
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Obama Calls for Overhaul of N.S.A.’s Phone Data Collection Program
item.description: President Obama, responding on Friday to months of debate set off by the disclosures of Edward J. Snowden, said he would require intelligence agencies to get court permission before tapping into a vast trove of phone data.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and PETER BAKER
item.media:description: In the front row at Mr. Obama's speech were his top security officials, from left to right: F.B.I. Director James B. Comey, C.I.A. Director John Brennan, Director of National Intelligence James Clapper and Homeland Security Secretary Jeh C. Johnson.

item.title: Top U.N. Official Describes ‘Horror’ in South Sudan
item.description: At the end of a four-day visit, a human rights official said “mass atrocities” had been committed, with reports of killings and sexual violence.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Blast at Antigovernment March Raises Tensions in Bangkok
item.description: The attack intensified tensions in the city as a dwindling but dedicated core of protesters continues to block access to a number of major intersections and government buildings.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Protesters were given first aid after an attack, most likely with a grenade.

item.title: Syria Proposes Cease-Fire in Aleppo
item.description: The proposal appeared to be an effort by the government to show good faith before a peace conference next week aimed at ending Syria’s civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Relatives and residents gathered and prayed around the bodies of children who were killed on Friday after rockets fired from Syria hit the Lebanese border town of Arsal.

item.title: Wife of Indian Minister Found Dead in Hotel Room After Twitter Row
item.description: - The wife of an Indian government minister was found dead in a New Delhi hotel room on Friday, police said, days after she was involved in a row with a Pakistani woman journalist over Twitter.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Britain Scrambles to Fill Skills Gap
item.description: Faced with a shortage of skilled manufacturing workers, the government and industry are behind a push to get teenagers into apprenticeships.
item.dc:creator: By KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Six years ago Liam Brooker started working as an apprentice at Brompton Bicycles, a London maker of foldable bicycles. Now he is the company's star at welding.

item.title: The Lede: A.P. Cameraman Released on Bail in Egypt
item.description: An Egyptian cameraman who was arrested this week while covering the constitutional referendum in Egypt for The Associated Press was released on bail on Friday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Israel Summons European Ambassadors to Complain
item.description: The Foreign Ministry told ambassadors from France, Britain, Italy and Spain that their countries had shown bias in favor of the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 17
item.description: Tribal fishermen taking part in the Jonbeel festival near Jagiroad, Assam.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Trial Begins Next Week for Human Rights Activist in China
item.description: Although the defendant, Xu Zhiyong, believes the outcome is a foregone conclusion, he will still fight the accusations in court, his lawyers said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Rahul Gandhi, Facing Tough Premier Race, Skips Formal Party Nomination
item.description: The decision not to seek the nomination is a tactic by a member of the family that has dominated India’s politics for decades.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Rahul Gandhi, vice president of the Congress party, spoke at the All India Congress Committee meeting in New Delhi on Friday.

item.title: India Ink: Suchitra Sen, Star of Bengali Cinema, Dies at 82
item.description: The actor became known as India’s Greta Garbo for her iconic performances and her reclusive ways after she quit acting over three decades ago.
item.dc:creator: By ANURADHA SHARMA

item.title: India Ink: What They Said: Rahul Gandhi’s Speech at Congress Executive Meeting
item.description: In an unusually passionate address on Friday, Rahul Gandhi praised the governing party as the defenders of the people’s will and criticized the main opposition as being undemocratic.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Lady Gaga to Sing Again in China with ‘Artpop’
item.description: More than two years after several of Lady Gaga’s songs were banned in China, the authorities are permitting her new album, “Artpop,” to go on sale.
item.dc:creator: By DONG NAN
item.media:description: The cover of Lady Gaga's "Artpop" album will be modified for the Chinese market.

item.title: Tension Rises Between Australia and Indonesia Over Migrant Patrols
item.description: The dispute follows Australia’s admission that its naval vessels inadvertently entered Indonesian waters while seeking to intercept boat people.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Use of Microblogs Drops Sharply Amid Crackdown
item.description: A crackdown on online speech and competition from smartphone messaging apps curtailed the popularity of services like Sina Weibo.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A man visits the Sina Weibo site on his smartphone.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Unveils New Native Operating System
item.description: The Chinese Academy of Sciences called COS, designed for use on many devices including smartphones and personal computers, a strategic product for national security.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Between China and Japan, a Tug-of-War Over Africa
item.description: On Africa, China is “sincere, unlike some countries” driven by self-interest and politics, said a top Chinese official making remarks after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan wrapped up a tour of the continent.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan sits between Ethiopia's prime minister, Hailemariam Desalegn, right, and the deputy chairman of the African Union Commission, Erastus Mwencha, during a visit to the African Union headquarters in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on Jan. 14.

item.title: Spread of Bird Flu Worries China Ahead of Peak Travel Time
item.description: The growing number of cases could pose a health threat as the world’s largest annual human migration begins ahead of Chinese New Year.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: India Ink: In Mumbai, One Day at the Stadium, Two Strains of Cricket
item.description: The author, a fan of long-form cricket, laments the big divide between the city’s much-ballyhooed Indian Premier League team and the scrappy, homegrown Ranji Trophy players.
item.dc:creator: By DILIP D'SOUZA
item.media:description: Ambati Rayadu, a Mumbai Indians cricketer, playing a shot in an I.P.L. match between Delhi Daredevils and Mumbai Indians at the Feroz Shah Kotla stadium in New Delhi on April 27, 2012.
